Or Violets cheeke, on which the morning leaves
A teare at parting, now begins to wither,
As it would haste to death, and be forgotten;
This Florence is a Prince that does accuse her;
And such men give not faith to every murmur
Or sight intelligence that wounds a Lady
In her deare hnour; but shee is my sister;
Thinke of that too; credit not all, but aske
Of thy owne veines what guilty flowings there
May tempt thee to beleeve this accusation.
Tis shee;
Th'art come Theodosia to my wishes.

SP.SPEAKER: Theo.
SP.L: What does distract you Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: I have done your message to the Duke, and finde
He does love Domitilla.

SP.SPEAKER: Theo.
SP.L: Her he shall meete and marry in Elisium.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: What meane you?

SP.SPEAKER: Theo.
SP.L: I have shooke off my tamenesse; doe not hinder
My just revenge; Ile turne their triumphs into death.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: There is a question of more consequence
Thou must resolve; it does concerne thee more
Then thy owne life.

SP.SPEAKER: Theo.
SP.L: You fright me.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Are you honest?

SP.SPEAKER: Theo.
SP.L: Honest.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: I could have us'd the name of chaste,
Or virgin; but they carry the same sence;
Put off thy wonder Theodosia,
And answer me by both our parents ashes,
Which now are frighted in the urne, and scarse
Contain'd beneath their marble, while their same
Bleeds in my wounded honour art thou still
My sister without stane; upon thy chastity
Tell me and answer truth, for both our lives.
Nay, nay, there is no time for thy amaze;
Hast thou not lost thy selfe and beene injoyed;
I blush to name the way.

SP.SPEAKER: Theo.
SP.L: Never.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Theo.
SP.L: By all the good we hope for I an innocent
As your owne wishes.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Th'art my vertuous sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Theo.
SP.L: But by your love and all that bound to
Be just, now let me know my strange accuser.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Thou shalt know that hereafter; let thy thoughts
Live in their owne peace, and dispute not mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.L: Not speake to me; he fround too; sure I have not
Displeasd him; wherefore stayes the Princesse?

SP.SPEAKER: Theo.
SP.L: Shew spirit now or never. Domitilla
The greatest part of my affliction;
Let my revenge begin here.

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.L: Your grace does honour your unworthy servan;
And if I might beseech one favour more,
Tis but to know what has displeas'd the King.

SP.SPEAKER: Theo.
SP.L: Must you be of counsell with his passions;
What hath advanc'd you to this boldnesse?

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.L: Pardo
Why does your grace put on those angry lookes;
I never did offend you in a thought.

SP.SPEAKER: Theo.
SP.L: Cunning dissembler, yes, and tis thy death
Must satisfie; yet ere I give thee punishment
Tell me what impudence advanc'd thy thoughts
So high in our dishonour was here none
In your owne for me of blood it for your love,
But you must flatter your prou? hopes with one
So much above thy birth though he in frailty
Consent to make thee great, dar thou accept it,
And with my shame aspite to be his equall;
Disclaime these hopes, and sweare never to love him.

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.L: Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Theo.
SP.L: Doe, or with this I will secue my feares,
And stand the malice of all other fate.

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.L: Heare me.

SP.SPEAKER: Theo.
SP.L: Be briefe.

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.L: I know not by what genius promptd Madam,
To live or die, more happily, I have no
Feare of your rage, which is so farre from making
Me sinne against my love, it has inlarg'd
My heart, which trembles not to be loves martyr;
I can forgive your hand too, if you promise
To tell the King how willing I die for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Theo.
SP.L: The King; thou lov'st the Duke.

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.L: Hee's not concern'd
In my affection; I have no thought
Of any Prince alive, but your owne brother;
Such an example of loves folly have
My starres decreed me; yet if pride and duty
May in one action meete and be good friends,
Both shall assist my last breath which shall offer
Humbly the King, and his affaires to heaven
This he will pardon, shall he know it done
By me more sit to die then live for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Theo.
SP.L: Alas poore Domitilla; shee is wounded
As deepe as I; rise and forgive my jealousie;
I cannot promise thee to be my sister,
But I will love thee like one; let us call
A counsell of our thoughts, and mingle sorrowes;
Yet when we have done all, and tyr'd our breath,
There is no cure for love, but love or death.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: How will Montalto counsell me; I am
Wilde with the repetition.

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: The Duke
Lay such a blacke aspersion on your sister;
Tis blasphemy to honour; but as soone
He may pollute the Sunne beames, or deile▪
The dew of heaven ere it approach the earth
Make us beleeve the rockes of ice doe flame,
And may indanger the north starre; my wonder
Will make me reasonlesseit throwes a poyson
On your whole family, a staine so deepe
And so prodigious, all the blood within
His Dukedome wo'not purge it; could he finde
No excuse for his revolt to Domitilla,
But blasting the sweet Princesse.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Domitilla
Whom I must tell you I already have
Prepar'd to be thy bride, as an addition
To the reward I owe thy services.

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: Prepard for me? you are too bountifull
In you I kneele both to my king and father;
But my aspiring will be satisfied
To be your servant still: in your grace I
Injoy the bride my heart affects; let me
Grow old with duties here, and not translate
My affection till my weary soule throw off
The burden of my dust.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: No more: in this
One act, Ile build a monument of my love
To thee, and my revenge upon the Duke;
Thou instantly shalt marry Domitilla;
Her Beauty, Blood and Fortune will deserve thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: I am your creature▪ but how this may inflame▪
The Duke.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Tis meant so.

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: But your sisters fame
Were worth your first care; this may be done
With more accesse of joy when shee is righted:
You have beene pleasd to heare my counsell Sir
And not repented.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: What would'st thou advise me?

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: The Duke is young and apt to erre; you cannot
Preserve your hospitable Lawes to affront
Him openly, nor will it be thought prudence
To let loose these suspitions to the descant
Of peoples tongues; th'aire is dangerous;
Let me search the Dukes bosome, for the spring
Of this dishonour.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: How?

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: Mistake me not;
Philoberto is his secret consellour,
And the receiver of his thoughts; leave me
To manage this great worke; I have a way
To every angle of his heart; meane time
Be pleas'd to keepe your person but retired;
A silent discontent will fright him more,
And arme us with full knowledge.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Wise Montalto,
I like thy honest counsell, and obey it;
But lose no time.

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: It never was more pretious;
My essence is concern'd and every minute
Brings a fresh seige against Montaltoes life;
There's none but Philoberto conscious
To my last accusation of the Princesse;
Then hee must be remov'd; delayes are fatall;
Ile poyson him to night; I have the way;
This done, the Duke may follow, or be brib'd
With Domitillaes person to quit Naples.

SP.SPEAKER: Guid.
SP.L: My honour'd Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: Guido, Aloisio;
Why make I this distinction y'are but one,
To your Montalto, have one heart and faith;
Your love and dilligence must now be active.

SP.SPEAKER: Guid.
SP.L: You have deserv'd us.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Lord of our fortunes.

SP.SPEAKER: Guid.
SP.L: Wee are your creatures,
Bound by all Law and conscience of the court
To serve your ends.

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: Tis but to waite close
And contrive excuses, if the Duke
Desire accesse to the King.

SP.SPEAKER: Gui.
SP.L: This all.

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: Be carefull
None of his traine nor faction be admitted,
In speciall Philoberto; if he appeare,
Present my service, and desire to speake with him;
This is no mighty Province gentlemen
To waste you much; yet this neglected will
Destroy my tall fate, in whote fall you must
Stoope and be strucken dead with the large ruines.

SP.SPEAKER: Gui.
SP.L: Kill us not first by your suspition;
We looke upon you as out destimy;
Prosper as we are faithfull.

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: You divide me.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: There is much trouble in his face, how ee
Let us be firme; is not this Philoberto.

SP.SPEAKER: Riv.
SP.L: My honor'd Lords.

SP.SPEAKER: Gui.
SP.L: We are proud to be your servants.
I am yours; where is the Lord Montalto.

SP.SPEAKER: Alo.
SP.L: New gone from us, and desires to speake with you,
And is gone either to your lodging or the Dukes.

SP.SPEAKER: Rivi.
SP.L: I have some affaires with the King, and that
Dispatch'd Ile waite upon him.

SP.SPEAKER: Gui.
SP.L: We are confident
You will excuse us; we receiv'd command
That none should interrupt him.

SP.SPEAKER: Rivi.
SP.L: I come from the Duke.

SP.SPEAKER: Alo.
SP.L: His excellenct will conster it our duties.

SP.SPEAKER: Riv.
SP.L: This was not wone.

SP.SPEAKER: Alo.
SP.L: We dar not sit dispute
Our masters pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Gui.
SP.L: Perhaps his confessor is with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Rivi.
SP.L: Perhaps there is some cunning; nay preserre
The businesse of the soule, I may presume
He has no long Catalogue to account for.

SP.SPEAKER: Gui.
SP.L: You have not beene of touneu with his conscience;
We doe not use to limit his devotions.

SP.SPEAKER: Rivi.
SP.L: Tis picus, and you three by
Montaltoes knaves here plac'd, to keepe away
Discoveries: in spight of all your subtilties,
The king shall know my minde, and understand
The history of your patrons and your service;
Let time speak your reward in your owne chronicles.

SP.SPEAKER: Alo.
SP.L: You not forget my Lord Montalto ha
Desire to speake with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Rivi.
SP.L: Tis all my businesse;
Be carefull of your watch and looke about you,
Some Wee sell may get in else.

SP.SPEAKER: Gui.
SP.L: Does he jeere us?

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Let him; his Embassy is not perform'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Mont,
SP.L: You doe amaze my understanding Si
To require I should justifie a tale
Made to the blemish of so chaste a Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Did not your Lordship tell such a story
To Philoberto in my lodging.

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: I date his molice, to afft; and tis not
Done like your selfe to sully with one breath
Two sames.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Shall I not credit my owne eares?

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: Deare Sir, collect your selfe, and let not passion
To Domitilla whom you may passesse,
Here after make you so unjust.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Deare Machiavill
This will not doe; the King shall know your stratagems.

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: Goe threaten babes; this would exalt my rage,
But I remember ,
Nor would I grieve the genius of my country,
To place my owne revenge above her honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Poore shaddow.

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: Now.
SP.STAGE: Drames a dagger at the Dukeanbarke.
SP.L: Twill not be safe; you know your change.

SP.SPEAKER: Guid.
SP.L: We are proud to sc your eace in health.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Where i the King?

SP.SPEAKER: Alo.
SP.L: A little Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Not yet I thinke, he is at his prayers.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.L: Ile adde to his Letanie.

SP.SPEAKER: Guid.
SP.L: It wo'not neede;
I thinke his ghostly father can direct him,
With whom he is in private.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: I know not
How to interpret this; I want Philoberto.

SP.SPEAKER: Octav.
SP.L: Your graces
Servant; he lookes displeas'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Guid.
SP.L: My Lord Octavio.

SP.SPEAKER: Octav.
SP.L: Your servant Lords.

SP.SPEAKER: Guid.
SP.L: You meet the Duke.

SP.SPEAKER: Octav.
SP.L: His face shewed discontnt.

SP.SPEAKER: Aloi.
SP.L: We summe our fortunes in Montaltoes smile,
By whose commands we have denyed the Duke
Accesse to'th King.

SP.SPEAKER: Octav.
SP.L: You have done well▪ it much
Concernes my Lord; his and all our fate
Depends upon't; continue still your care
And circumspction, and while I am within
Let none be admitted.

SP.SPEAKER: Guid,
SP.L: Let us alone;
A spirit may have the device to enter,
But if he have so much body as a Gnat
Ile know his errand; whoes this; oh it tis
My Lady Domitillaes Secretary.

SP.SPEAKER: Bom.
SP.L: Here are so many trickes, and turnes, and dores
I'these Court lodgings, I have lost my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Guid.
SP.L: Mr. Secretary.

SP.SPEAKER: Bom.
SP.L: Twas you betrayd me to the King, and caus'd
My Ladies to be sent for, with more cunning
To bring me hither; but alls one, he has
Not seene me yet not sha'not; which
Is my ay out of this labyrinth.

SP.SPEAKER: Alo.
SP.L: Why are you so unwilling the King should see you?

SP.SPEAKER: Guid.
SP.L: Or to live in Court; me thinkes this habite
Becomes you now; doe it not my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: He lookes like a true Hero.

SP.SPEAKER: Bom.
SP.L: You are beside the story Sir; I did reade once
That Hero had no upper lip; shee was
A Lady of Leanders lake.

SP.SPEAKER: Guid.
SP.L: A wit? theres a new word; now for the Hellespont,
Heele make a subtile courtier.

SP.SPEAKER: Bm.
SP.L: It has undone me.

SP.SPEAKER: Alo.
SP.L: Vndone thee how?

SP.SPEAKER: Bom.
SP.L: I know not whether it be my wit or clothes,
Or disposition of the place, or all
Together, but I am sue I am in love,
I finde it by the losing of my stomacke;
I am most strangely in love.

SP.SPEAKER: Guid
SP.L: With whom?

SP.SPEAKER: Bom.
SP.L: I know not.

SP.SPEAKER: Aloi.
SP.L: Can you not guesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Bom.
SP.L: I hope tis with my selfe, for I did vow
When my first mistresse dyed which was,

SP.SPEAKER: Guid.
SP.L: What?

SP.SPEAKER: Bom.
SP.L: A dairy maide that we had i'th Countrey,
To love no living woman bove an houre;
Shee was the very creame of all her Sex;
Oft have we churn'd together.

SP.SPEAKER: Guid.
SP.L: And drunke healths
In Butter-milke.

SP.SPEAKER: Aloi.
SP.L: But doe you hope you are in love with your selfe Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bom.
SP.L: Marry doe I Sir; is that so wonderfull at Court.

SP.SPEAKER: Guid.
SP.L: You are pleasant.

SP.SPEAKER: Aloi.
SP.L: Lets be rid on him.

SP.SPEAKER: Guid.
SP.L: Come you shall now speake with the King,
And he shall knight thee; more honours may follow.

SP.SPEAKER: Bom.
SP.L: You shall excuse me; put your honours
Vpon some body else.

SP.SPEAKER: Guid.
SP.L: Doe you know what tis.

SP.SPEAKER: Bom.
SP.L: I have not read of late.

SP.SPEAKER: Aloi.
SP.L: But you are much given to hearing,
What is honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Bom.
SP.L: Honour a buble is that is soone broke,
A Gloworme seeming fire, but has no smoake.

SP.SPEAKER: Aloi.
SP.L: There's fire and water.

SP.SPEAKER: Bom.
SP.L: And smoake for ayre;
A painted Sun-beame, peece of gilded Chaffe,
And he that trusts leanes to a broken staffe.

SP.SPEAKER: Gui.
SP.L: You should have reconcil'd the foure elements
To the conceit; there was fire, aire, water;
Wheres the earth.

SP.SPEAKER: Bom.
SP.L: Oh he that leanes to a broken staffe shall
Finde that presently.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter King reading a paper, Octavio.

SP.SPEAKER: Guid.
SP.L: The King.

SP.SPEAKER: Bom.
SP.L: King bee your leave; I vanish.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: This paper containes wonder; tis not possible.

SP.SPEAKER: Octa.
SP.L: Vpon my lise Sir, Philoberto can demonstate these.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: The Divell has not art
To abuse us so; this will require some counsell;
Hee's here,
Montalto; leave us.

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: Sir your pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Is all in thee; hast met with Philoberto?

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: Not yet.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: No matter; I have thought upon't,
And doe conclude it best to let things passe
Yet in a dreame; choise and enquiry may
Awake suspition upon innocence.

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: You cannot thinke her guilty Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: I am not
Without some feares; I have collected things
Since we conferr'd, that stagger my good thoughts.

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: Of her you cannot; Sir unthinke agen,
What ever would betray her to your jealousy;
A Virgins Monument cannot be more chaste
Ith Temple.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Yes, yes; we may be all cozend;
And therefore let her passe among things desperate;
Yet were I crtaine shee were spotted thus,
As tis but a young Leprosie upon her,
I could wish heartily my Sister timely
Married, not to the Duke that would betray us,
But to some one I know not, who could love
Vs both, so well as be that rare friend
And save our honours.

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: Doe you then suspect her.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Oh the Dukes Character had a powerfull sence;
And who knowes but shee may be lost by one
Not fit to make her reparation;
Could any Nobleman be found in Naples
To binde her wound up by so great an act
Of secrecy and marriage; but some winde
May listen and convey, I know not whether,
What my sad breath has scatter'd in the aire;
Thy Master has no servant that dares take
One sorrow from him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: You are Sir provided
Of more then that can rise to in my service.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Canst thou be so compassionate to lose
Thy hopes of richer beauty, for my sake?
Darst thou with all this knowledge hide her stain,
And marry her?

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: My duty to your Majestie
Shall marry me to death; let not this trouble
The quiet of your heart; Ile take Theodosia,
And thinke upon her as shee had the whitenesse
Of my good Angell.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Th'art a miracle;
Teach me but which way I may reward this love;
Till now I had no poverty; thy worth
Will make me everlastingly in debt;
What shall I say?

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: Great Sir, no more; your favours
Flow from a bounty, which hath onely heaven
Above it.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: They are all trifles; let me see,
Is nothing in thy power to make thee finde
My gratitude? how barren are we, wealth,
Honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: Ther's nothing good or great you have not
Freely possest me with; your favours would,
So mighty have they falne upon me, rather
Expresse a storme, and I had suke beneath
The welcome violence, had not your love
From whence they flowed, inabled me to strength
And manly bearing.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: I was inprovident
To reserve nothing, or it was a fault
In thee to be so prodigall of merit
In thy past services; canst thou thinke of nothing
Worth my addition.

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: Nothing Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: I have it,
And thanke my better genim I have it,
Such a reward Montalto that I dare
Be modest yet pronounce, never did Prince
Exceede it to his friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: Sir you amaze me,
And shame my want of merit.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: In the title,
Let Kings peruse the benefit and study
An imitation to their best loved creatures;
Th'are great as fortune can invent; Ile teach thee
A way Montalto, to know all thy friends.
And enemies.

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: That were a pretious knowledge,
Were it in nature; with your highnesse pardon
The hearts of men are not to be measured
With what we reach the starres, fadome Seas;
Oh he thats active in a state has more.
Chainde to him by the power and strength of office,
Then genuine respect; and tis not worth
Or person, but the fortunes of a Statesman
That sometimes men adore.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Tis true; and therefore
I am prud in this that I can teach thee looke
Into mens soules, to know 'em fit for scorne, or
Thy embraces.

SP.SPEAKER: Mon.
SP.L: How may this Sir be done?

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Almost 'ith twinckling of an eye too.

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: Strange.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: I seeme to frowne upon thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: How Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Doest apprehend me; I will counterfeit
That I am displeas'd with thee; doe not mistake me,
And have it voic'd about the Court, thou art
Consin'd, doest marke; at this will all thy enemies
Whose hearts thou canst not see, their tongues before
By thy great power silend, joyne in faction
Complaine, discover their whole stocke of malice,
Tickling their spleenes, that thou art out of favour,
Whom I shall heare and smile at; then all those
Whose honest soules deserve thee, will rise up,
The champions of thy same o'th other side
And be so many Oratours to make
Thy faith and honour shine; when this done,
The scene is chang'd, I send for thee; thou commest
With a most glorious traine; and then Ile smile,
Take thee agen i'th sight of all, discover
Twas but a tricke, thy friends keepe still thy bosome,
And thou in triumph shoot'st a scorne with mine
To strike all envie dumbe; Ist not a rate one?
I cannot doe enough for thee Montalto.

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: You have found out a way I must confesse;
But with your pardon, I shall be more able
To do: you service in the other ignorance,
Then ru a desperate hazard in this knowledge;
Some hold it sinne, and capitall enough
To have the Princes favour, which once lost
Though but in suspition; they may rage,
And like a torrent rise to o'rewhelme nature.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: These sha'not wound thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: And how other Indges
May wrest the actions of a man imployed
Though ne're so faithfull to his King and state.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: I am confident of thy justice and decree,
Thy triumph in't; thy goodnesse thus concuous
Renders thee loved, and fit for Theodosia
When she is brightest; the Sunne never smi
More cherefull upon teeming earth,
Then I to finde thee perfect; for I doe
But seeme displeas'd; come, I will have it so;
If thou dost love me, no dispute, but let me
Pursue my fancie meant to doe thee honour.
Who waites?
Now it begins;
Attend my Lord Montalto to his Chamber,
Where our will is, he be consin'de untill
Our pleasure further knowne.

SP.SPEAKER: Guid.
SP.L: How's this?

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Aloi. Consin'd!

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: No ceremony Sir; when that's done,
We ease you of the trouble too of waiting;
You know the way my Lords to your owne lodgings,
From whence on perill of our anger stirre not
Vntill wee send for you—Octavio.

SP.SPEAKER: Guid.
SP.L: Doe we not dreame.

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: Something wo'd creepe
Like a dead sleepe upon me; I am in
A Labirinth; but hence with coward feare;
I know the worst; grim death can but translate
Me hence, and there's an end of death and fate.

DIV2.HEAD: The fift Act.

SP.SPEAKER: Theo.
SP.L: He conforted and counsel'd Domitilla;
I have my part in loves affliction.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: This I fear'd
I must acquaint the King; where is your fellow
Bombo? his mirth might now be seasonable.

SP.SPEAKER: Iaca.
SP.L: Hee's gone Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: Gone, whither?

SP.SPEAKER: Iaca.
SP.L: Backe to the country house; he heard of my Lord
Montaltoes disgrace, and the feare of his supp'ying
The place of a favorite, sent him away this morning
With all his moveables; the countrey he saies
Is wholesome, where he will dye without feare or wit when
His time comes; he durst not stay to see the King.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: Would we had still beene strangers to the Court;
Leave us; my daughter is much bound to your grace.

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.L: It is the King you speake of; pray be carefull
You speake all goodnesse of him, he deserves it,
And will when I am dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: Ile lose no time.

SP.SPEAKER: Theo.
SP.L: I wish it prosper.

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.L: I dare not say the King dissembles with me;
That were a fault beyond my love; but sure
Something he said that made my heart beleeve
He did not meane me for another; and
Montalto, whose reward I must be thought,
Is now consin'd, and under his displeasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Theo.
SP.L: He will have more care of his honour then
To place thee so unworthily; Montalto
Has plaid the cunning traytour with our loves,
If I may trust thee noble Philoberto
That told me the whole story of his falsehood,
Which I before suspected.

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.L: And if he should dispise me as tis justice,
Will heaven be angry if I love him still;
Or will the King call it a treason in me?
If hee doe, I can willingly dye for't,
And with may last words pray he may live happy;
But why am I this trouble to your grace?
My story is not worth one of your minuts;
Deare Madam pardon me, and teach me how
To make my time more happy, spent in something
That may concerne your highnesse; you doe love too.

SP.SPEAKER: Iaca.
SP.L: Madam, the Duke of Florence.

SP.SPEAKER: Theo.
SP.L: How the Dake?

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.L: Why does he visite me? Madam indeed
You may beleeve I love him not.

SP.SPEAKER: Theo.
SP.L: Admit him
I preethe, and conceale me Domitilla;
I know he comes a wooing to thy beauty;
I preethe let me heare the second part:

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.L: I shall against my owne desires obey you.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: The ambition of my eyes can not be thought
Immodest, if they ever wish to dwell here;
They have found their light agen; let no misfortune
Be a second cause to bury me in darkenesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.L: Your graces pardon, if my haste to attend
The King and his commands made me appeare
Rude when I left your excellence.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: This does more
Then satisfie.

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.L: I know not how I may
Stand guilty in your thoughts by keeping a
Rich Caskanet.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: You honor'd me to accept it.

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.L: But with a blush I must remember too
I did not thanke you; there was want of time
Or manners; I must leave it to your mercy,
And would by any duty to your grace
Expiate my errour.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Madam it is not worth
The mention of this gratitude; Your breath
Makes the oblation rich, and me who am
Encourag'd by your , to present you
With something of more valew, then a world
Of these poore empty glories; I dare give you
My heart Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.L: Blesse your grace from such a meaning.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Can you be cruell to it?

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.L: I ne're had
The confidence to looke upon a wound;
And such a bleeding object as your heart
Would fright my senses.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: You are more ingenious
Then not to understand that I meane love;
I love you Madam, best of all your sex.

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.L: You cannot Sir, you dare not.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: How?

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.L: You dare not be so wicked I am am sure
When you remember, what you are, a Prince.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Is it a sinne for Princes to love Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.L: Or if you could dispence with so much passion
To love me, and durst give me, what I tremble
To thinke you promise, that, that very act
In which you most advance affection to me,
Would make me thinke you love me not.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Be clearer.

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.L: How should I thinke his courtship worth my trust,
And meete him with a reall change of hearts,
Who in his very first attempt of love,
Would blast my honour, and betray me to
A shame, blacke as the tongue of infamy.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Would I?

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.L: And more;
For you in this
Would tempt me to an act, by which I should
Not onely wound my selfe to death of honour,
But make me guilty of anothers blood,
And kill an innocent Lady, whose least teare
Is worth a thousand lives of perjurd men
That make a scorne of vertue.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: What Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.L: Have you forgot the Princesse Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: The Princesse!

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.L: In that name youle finde your selfe agen
Lost in a mist of passions; oh thinke
The fames and hopes of two rich countries are
Engag'd upon your faith; your highnesse pardon,
I finde some blushes chide my too much boldnesse,
And by a nearer view now of your goodnesse,
I see my errour to beleeve you meant
Other then trill of me, or could fall
To any thought beneath your birth and honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: But if Theodosia be made anothers
By her owne gift, and I at large, with what
Justice may I be thought then to addresse
My passions hither.

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.L: If the Princesse, which
I must not thinke, give your heart backe agen,
And that you could quit all your tyes with honour,
My thoughts are all resign'd to the Kings will;
He must dispose of me, by my owne vow,
Without his free conlent never to marry.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: The King; there tis; I thought shee was his mistresse;
Tis not possible the Princesse now
Can pardon my neglect; Montaltoes practise
Vpon me, and his poysoning of her vertue
Wo'not excuse my shame; I dare not see
Whom I have injur'd, Theodosia;
In am resolv'd, this ight Ile eae from Naples.

SP.SPEAKER: Theo.
SP.L: Nay doe not hide your face my Lord; it will
Appeare as fresh and lovely to my eyes,
As when it first presented me your smiles;
I am Theodosia still.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: But I have beene?

SP.SPEAKER: Theo.
SP.L: Abus'd; time will discover to the ruine
Of his owne name, and glory of our loves,
Montaltoes practise to divide our sonles.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: You cannot be so mercifull; or else
This sweetnefle is put on to enlarge my guilt,
When we are both compar'd; dare you beleeve
I can repent and be'reveng'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Theo.
SP.L: Vpon whom?

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Vpon my selfe, for suffering my ye
To wander from this sweetnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Theo.
SP.L: You outdoe
The satisfaction; if your grace can finde
Me grow agen within your heart, where first
My love desired to plant.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Oh let me drowne
My blushes in this over slow of charity;
But there's an act that justice calls me to,
Before I can be worthy of this peace.
Montalto has plaid the villaine; now I finde it,
And from his treacherous heart my sword must force
A bloody satisfaction for thy honour,
Poyson'd by him.

SP.SPEAKER: Theo.
SP.L: Stay that revenge; shame has
Already sunke him.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.L: Sir the King desires
Some conference with your grace, and with you Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Theo.
SP.L: I shall attend you Sir; we shall present
Together, thus no object to displese him.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Though I shall blush to see him, Ile waite on you.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Good heaven, upon what humane bosome shall
We that are made your substitutes on earth
Place secure confidence? and yet there may
Be malice in complaints; the flourishing Oake
For his extent of Branches, state, growth,
The darling and the Idoll of the wood,
Whose awefull nod the under trees adore,
hooke by a tempest, and throwne downe must need
ubmit his curled head and full growne limbes,
o every common Axe, be patient, while
he tortures put to every joynt the Sawes
nd engines, making with their very noyse
he Forrests groane and tremble; but not one
When it was in his strength and state revil'd it,
Whom poverty of soule, and envy sends
To gather stickes from the trees wish'd for rume,
The great mans Embleme; I did love Montalto,
And wed not have him lost if justice would
Consent, and be a little of his side;
But here are the two plummets weigh him downe;
His impious practice on the Duke, and base
Aspertions on our sister that defame
Our whole blood, is a loud, loud accusation.

SP.SPEAKER: Rivi.
SP.L: His conscience dares not Sir deny't.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: And you
Speake here the tragicke story of Riviro,
Whose honest soule for not complying with
His power and ends, chose in a discontent
To make himselfe an exile, yee pursude,
And by the practise of Montalto poyson'd
At Rome.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: This letter sent to Alvarez,
Whose Physicke purg'd his soule away,
Is too much testimony.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Tis his Character.
Octavio you come for justice too.

SP.SPEAKER: Octav.
SP.L: It were a vaine breath to desire it Sir;
Your thoughts are still so conscious of vertue,
They will prevent petition.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Come nearer.

SP.SPEAKER: Rivi.
SP.L: The King is troubled.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: Where he loved, to finde
So much ingratitude.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Andrugi.

SP.SPEAKER: Rivi▪
SP.L: Things are not yet mature for my discovery.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: You observe—away—
We may be just Philoberto,
Yet not destroy another attribute,
Which shewes whose repre sentative we are;
Mercy becomes a King; too much can be
But thought a sinne on the right hand; we are
Resolv'd.
Madam you are welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Rivi.
SP.L: I begin
To feare there is some spell upon the King;
If after this Montalto shall prevaile,
Let innocence be stronger to the world,
And heaven be afraid to punish vice.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Remove
For a few minuts.

SP.SPEAKER: Rivi.
SP.L: I obey.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: You tell me wonders Madam; las poore Lady,
I shall then have enough to reconcile;
Shee was too hasty to interpret me
Her lover.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: If you Sir apply no cure,
The fond impression may I feare indanger
Her sence and life; I urg'd Montalto Sir
By your command, before his change of fortun,
But shee tooke no delight to heare him namde.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: No, no, nor I; good heaven how I am troubled
How to repaire this pretty peece of innocence,
Whom I have brought into a waking dreame
Of passion; something I must doe; pray tell me,
But tell me truth; I charge thee by thy duty
To me, to Naples, and to heaven, or if
There be in womans faith, or thy Religion
Any thing else to make it up a full
And perfect conjuration.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: You fright me;
Without these not a thought within my heart
But you have power to summon.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Tell me then,
Is D mitilla vertuous?

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: How Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Is shee exceeding vertuous; is she most
Divinely chast; can shee doe more then blush
At wanton sounds; will shee be'very angry
At an immodest offer, and be frighted
To heare it nam'd; tell me; does shee pray
And weepe, and wod be torne upon the racke
Ere shee consent to staine one virgin thought:
Or dares shee more then Lucrece kill her selfe
To save her honour, or doe something more
Miraculously then all this to preserve
Her white name to posterity.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: I know not
How to reply to these particulars;
But if your meaning be to have me speake
Truth of her modest and pare thoughts, shee is
All that her mother can beseech of heaven
To blesse a childe with of so chast a soule,
And vertuous simplicity.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: No more;
I doe beleeve, and will finde out a way
To make her satisfaction; tis just;
Say I desire her presence.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: Now you blesse us;
A widdowes prayers and teares for this great bounty.

SP.SPEAKER: Rivi.
SP.L: Your sister and the Duke Sit.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: There's new trouble.

SP.SPEAKER: Rivi.
SP.L: Never so lovingly united;
The pleasant language of their eyes and gestutes
Doth speake their hearts at peace.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: That would rejoyce me.

SP.SPEAKER: Theo.
SP.L: Take us to your love;
All jealousies are banish'd, and we both
Breath from one soule.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: My wonder and my joy.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Your pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Take my bosome.

SP.SPEAKER: Theo.
SP.L: The misfortune
Kept us at distance, was your cratures act.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: The clouds are now remov'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Rivi.
SP.L: Lord Montalto, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Let Musicke speake
His deare approach; we sent for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Rivi.
SP.L: How's this:

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Let me intreate you to obscute your persons
A while.

DIV2.STAGE: Lond Musicke—Enter Guido, Aloisio, Alexio, Andrugio, Octavio, Montalto.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: My Lord y'are welcome to us, very welcome
We have kept our word, and finde you have not lost
Your confidence; what a brave armour is
An innocent soule? How like a ocke it bids
Defiance to a storme, against whose ribbes
The insolent waves, but dash themselves in peeces,
And fall and hide their heads in passion
How would a guilty person tremble now,
Looke pale, and with his eyes to the ground
Betray his feare of justice.

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: Where should honour
Shine with his pure and
Where there is such a King, so good, so great,
The example and reward; he must be
A rebell twice to that can live
To be convinc'd of a dishonour neare
Such an instructive goodnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Where be all his fierce accusets?
Call 'em to his presence,
Whom all their envies would destroy.

SP.SPEAKER: Rivi.
SP.L: So, so;
The King is charm'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Octav.
SP.L: They are gone upon the first
Newes of my Lords they vanish'd Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: So may all reason fly the brow of innocence▪

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Tis well said; but they sha not fly their names;
Reade there just to our thoughts, they apprehended
Thee lost in our displeasure (wheres our sister)
And now they came to be reveng'd Montalto,
Vpon our favours.

SP.SPEAKER: Guid.
SP.L: Right, and please your grace.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Theres something may concerne your want of grace
Andrugio, Philoberto.

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: We are undone Guido, and I see more
Engines are leveld at my fate.

SP.SPEAKER: Rivi.
SP.L: The King would have your Lordship peruse this.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: And these.

SP.SPEAKER: Rivi.
SP.L: That you may know your friends and enemies.

SP.SPEAKER: Mont▪
SP.L: Lost, lost for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Rivi.
SP.L: Sir you know
You have obliged the Princesse Theodosia
And the Duke to you, and you may presume
To use their favours, they are here.

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: Twere better
For me they had no beeing. I did never
Expect this; to accuse me for the death
Of Riviero; but I must obey
This fatall revolution.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Why does Montalto kneele.

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: I dare not aske your pardon,
Onely I beg you would put on a brow
Rough as the cause you have to make it frowne,
And that may strike me dead without more torment.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Ingratefull man! am I rewarded thus▪
Not onely with my faith abus'd and subjects,
But wounding all our honours.

SP.SPEAKER: Theo.
SP.L: Let him finde your mercy Sir
For his offence to me.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: I must not, dare not pardon; twere a sinne
In me of violence to heaven and justice.

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: You have beene a Royall Master.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Take him hence;
His life will draw a scorne upon the Kingdome;
Expect the censure of or lawes you gentlemen▪
We onely banish from the court.

SP.SPEAKER: Gui. Aloi. Alex.
SP.L: You are mercifull.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Pray and be honest.

SP.SPEAKER: Rivi.
SP.L: That last wll be the greatest

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: My passion would be strong but here is one
Come to divert the streame; how is it with
My pretty Domitilla; you and I
May change some words in private.

SP.SPEAKER: Octav.
SP.L: The King is just, and tis within your silence
To make Montalto nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Rivi.
SP.L: Hee will sinke
Apace without that weight upon him; malice
Shall have no share in my revenge.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: And since Montalto
Is become incapable,
I wo'not marry thee; that a thing too common?
But thou shalt be my mistresse, a preferment
Above my first intention; be wise
And entertaine it; oh the dayes and nights
Weele spend together.

SP.SPEAKER: Octav.
SP.L: The King's very pleasant
With Domitilla.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Come kisse me
Domitilla; kisse me now
Before all these; what needs this modesty;
Come let us take in one anothers soule.

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.L: Are you the King of Naples.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: So they call me,
And if there be a power within that name
It shall be thine to make thee glorious,
And great above our Queene; there is no title
ike unto that our heate and blood creates
A mistresse Domitilla.

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.L: Are you Sir in earnest?

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Doe but thou consent, and I
Will give thee such a proofe in my embraces
Of the delight; they will not follow us;
tell thee more i'th bed-chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.L: I dare
Not understand this language▪ can the King
Be impious; how was my opinion cozen'd
Sinne hath deform'd his very shape; his voyce
Hath now no harmony.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: This is but to draw
More courtship from me.

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.L: Pardon I beseech you;
I have found my errour.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Will shee yeeld?

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.L: I did consent
Too soone to my captivity,
Though modesty would not allow me strength
To tell you so; but you have Sir, by what
My fond thoughts never did expect, reliev'd me,
to make me know my selfe; and now preserving
That duty which I owe you as my King,
I call love backe agen, and can looke on
Your lusts with a becomming scorne.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: You can.

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.L: Yes, and were Naples, Rome, and all the wealth
Of Italy laid downe, the great temptation,
Thus I would spurne their glories.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Come this is but the tricke of all your sex;
We know you can dissemble appetite,
As if you were not slesh and blood.

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.L: Sir give
Me leave to goe while I have power to pray for you,
Where was I lost? is there no friend to goodnesse;
Have I contracted such a leprous forme
That I have lost all mens defence and charity.

SP.SPEAKER: Octav.
SP.L: Madam your innocence doth raise in me,
Though young, a willing champion, and with
My safe obedience to the King, I dare,
Armde with the witnesse of her cause, defie
The greatest souldier in the world.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: How's this?

SP.SPEAKER: Octav.
SP.L: Sir, in a noble canse, if you to whom
In the first place truth flies as to an Altar,
Wave her religious defence I dare dye for her.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: You so brave? to prison with him;
We will correct your saucinesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Octav.
SP.L: You will grace
My first act Sir, and get me same by suffering
For so much sweetnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.L: Let not your displeasure
Great Sir fall upon him; revenge what you
Call disobedience here.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: You owe much to
His confidence; nor is there any punishment
Beyond your love and liking of his boldnesse;
You two should make a marriage with your follies.

SP.SPEAKER: Octav.
SP.L: Let Domitilla make Octavio
So blest.

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.L: My Lord you now deserve I should
Be whom with the hazard of the Kings
Anger, and your owne life you have defended;
There is a spring of honour here, and too it
th presence of the King, his Court and Heaven,
dare now give my heart; nor is't without
My duty to a promise.

SP.SPEAKER: Octav.
SP.L: Now you make
Octavio happy.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Tis to my desires,
nd I dare wish you joyes; forgive this practise;
ay preety Domitilla I did this
ut to divert more happily thy thoughts
f me, who have not paide yet the full tribute
my Cesarias dust; agen let me
ongratulate thy choise in young Octavio,
hose birth and forward vertue will deserve thee;
other and sister love, and wish them happinesse.
Theo. May all joyes spring within their hearts.
Duke. I must present this gentleman to be more knowne to you
Octav. I hope you are no enemy to this blessing.
Sim. I adde what doth become a most glad mother,
blessing to your loves.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Noble Riviero.

SP.SPEAKER: Rivi.
SP.L: I live agen by your acknowledgment.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Sir you may trust my testimony; Alvarez
Letter is now an argument of his safety,
Who is yet living to increase the guilt
Of false Montalto.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Welcome; tis thy life
That hath revers'd Montaltoes doome, whose sentence
Now shall bee onely banishment; our hearts
Are full and sprightly; nothing wants but to
Perfect with holy ceremony, what
Your hearts have seal'd; mirth in each bosome flowes,
Distraction never had so sweet a close.

DIV1.HEAD: THE EPILOGVE.
As it vvas spoken to the Lord Deputie on Newyeares-day at night, by way of vote, congratulating the New yeare.

LG.L: OVr Poet doth forget his Play;
There is something he would pay
Due to your greatnesse, and the day
Which by a revolution of the spheare
Is proud to open the New yeare.
And having look'd on you, hath hid his face,
And Chang'd his robe with Starres to grace
And light you going to bed, so waite
With trembling Lustre on your state.
Shine brighter yet, y'are not the same
Cleare Lampes you were shine like the name
Of him I bow too, while aflame
Active, and burning here with pure desires
Shall equall the best borrowed fires.
May health, the bosomes friend, streame through your blood,
And know no ebbe of the chast flood,
And though time shift, and yeares renew,
May yet the Spring be still in you.
May She, whom heaven hath sweetly grac'd
And in your noble bosome plac'd,
Whose heart by onely yours embrac'd,
Hath made one true, and holy Gordian, prove
Fruitfull in Children, as in love.
And may this faire Top-branch, whose early bloome
Doth promise all the fruit can come
To vertue, and your name be blest,
And live a story to the rest.
All Honour with your fame in crease,
In your bosome dwell soft peace,
And Iustice, the true roote of these;
Wealth be the worst, and out side of your fate;
And may not heaven your life translate,
Till for your Royall Master, and this Ile,
Your deeds have fild a Chronicle,
In all thats great, and good, be bold,
And every yeare be coppie of the old.
